content.description: The name pretty much says it all.
content.location: Follow the directions for The Butterknife and walk 15 feet up the hill.

content.description: Pretty sure this is “the trunk” in the Parking Lot boulders section. Sit start on the the steep sloping aretè. Work up and right to the vertical aretè. Figure out how to turn the corner and move straight up. Hard!
content.location: On the Bishop boulder.

content.description: According to Brady Callahan "start as low as you can go." Then, climb the obvious crack feature while trying to avoid the tree.
content.location: To the right of "warm-up boulder."

content.description: This shares a start with Bishup Bolder Direct. Pull on and bump the left to one of the starting crimps on Bishup. This is the crux, especially for a tall person. Roll out right to another sidepull that's far and low, then get to the big crimp at head hight. Then, traverse right until you get to another large, incut crimp and match. The feet are tricky. From here, you top out trending slightly left.As a note, this is a deliberate alternate exit to Bishup Bolder Sit. Rather than exiting up and left off of the first big crimp at head hight, I wanted to use the holds that go right as they add some technical moves and a different topout.As I note on Bishup Bolder Sit, the crux is a small box to fit in. It might be easier for a shorter person, so I would love to get people's thoughts on that. It's really hard to grade a single hard move like that, so take this grade with a grain of salt.Could be easier, or harder.
content.protection: a few pads at the bottom, and an extra couple to throw over the rock and tree behind you.
content.location: This is on the Bishup Boulder.

climbs.name: Short and Sharp (on Balls to Walls Bldr)

content.description: Not sure of the FA. I cleaned the key holds, but further cleaning may be helpful.Sit start on a small left hand crimp, and a right hand pinch/crimp with a good left foot. Pull up left to a sharp crimp, and throw out right to a good pinch. Rock-over and top out.
content.location: Directly right of the problem “Balls to the Wall.” On the side of the boulder facing the big wall.

content.description: Sit start under the right arete jug on some crimps, use terrible feet and incredible finger strength to make your way to the friendly jug of Righty, then finish up as desired.
content.location: under the right arete.

content.description: Climb the right arêt on the Dave Graham Boulder (this has PPE on the face). Start standing and work your way to the top until mantling over the edge.
content.location: Follow the hiking trail until you hit an intersection, which will go uphill to the left. Follow this for 2-3 minutes and you'll see the DGB on your left about 50 feet off the trail.

content.description: If you like crimps, then this is the boulder for you. Stand start with your fingers in the horizontal seam.  Throw big to a crimp.  Bump again to another crimp (depending on your height) and then slap out to the arete to top out.
content.protection: Flat landing with only 1 obstruction to pad out. 2-3 pads should do the trick.
content.location: Approach 1: If you entered into Tier 1 directly from the kiosk area, continue along the cliff band until you pass the lichen slab problem.  Continue walking up and left along a line of large boulders to your left.  This Triangular boulder is located up the hill around 150-200 paces depending on your height.Approach 2: Option 2 is to stay hiking on the boulder loop trail.  Take the left at the junction and walk uphill on the trail.  The Triangular boulder is located to your left and is visible from the trail.

content.description: Start sitting far right on the Marmalute boulder. Make a few powerful moves up the short arêt, gain the lip, and traverse all the way to the left where Marmalute tops out.
content.protection: 4 pads or someone to follow you with 1.
content.location: Stand facing No Use For A Name. Turn left 90° plus a little extra. Voila! You’ll see the boulder 10 feet from you.

climbs.name: No Use For A Name (Blundercling Boulder)

content.description: Sit start on the big side pull edge low on the face. Pull on and move straight up on crimps to a left hand side pull in the roof. Smear the right foot and stab for the shallow 3 finger pocket. Turn hips and set up for a dyno to the lip. Fun, hard problem.There is a left hand exit using the arete that is a little easier. William Leung posted a good video of it to the main page of this section.
content.location: Opposite side of the Blundercling problem.

content.description: Break out your Send pads and strap them on for a wild ride! Sit start in the small cave and use an excellent kneebar to get off the ground while matched on the undercling.  Establish into the crack out right and find the second kneebar! Follow the crack to the top and mantel out.Word on the street Northdivison only sends with a kneebar pad on.
content.location: This route is on the blundercling boulder which is the first boulder you will encounter on the trail when entering from the kiosk.  Either walk through the squeeze pass to the left of blundercling or walk around right.

content.description: Fun little problem with friendly holds. Sit start on the sloping ledge on the left side of the boulder. Work up and right to the aretè, then make a big move right to a good hold in the horizontal. Continue up the pillar to the top.
content.location: Directly behind the blunder cling boulder. Up the hill. Far left side, facing the trail.

content.description: This route isn't a king line by any means, but it has very good movement. After an awkward start with a left hand on the obvious large crimp, put your right hand down low on a small crimp and body tension to pull your feet on. Three hard and powerful moves make up the middle, and then it's all over at the top.
content.location: It's directly visible from the hiking trail. Only about 500 feet from the entrance kiosk.

content.description:
Stand stand and work your way up the tips crack. 

  A sit start is possible and considerably harder (at least V5).
content.location: Follow the directions for The Butterknife. This boulder is up the hill to the right.  Directly opposite of Bishup Bolder.

content.description: Sit or Squat low on the right side of the lichen slab boulder and climb the arete to the top. Fun Warmup!
content.location: Find the lichen slab, this is the right arete of it.

content.description: Stand start the arete and climb on the gigantic happy holds to a fun topout.
content.location: Just right of north division memorial problem.

content.description: Start with hands matched on a good crimp and a left heel hook.  Make a big move up the arete and match again.  Work your way up the arete to top out.
content.location: This boulder is on the other side of the boulder with The Butterknife. Walk on the trail past Blundercling. You will get to a part of the trail that has many boulders on it and a big, blank overhang on the right.  Turn left off the trail and walk up the hill. Look for the obvious overhang of The Butterknife and go to the other side.

content.description: Climb the left of the two seams on wall between Tier 1 and 2. Landing is pretty good and the top out is fun.
content.location: See Photo.

content.description: Stand start on crimps and climb straight up the face.
content.location: This is the first face you see when you walk to the top of the wooden stairs. In front of the Blundercling boulder.

content.description: Sit start where the normal “warm-up“ problem is. Instead of going straight up, traverse left on flakes and edges and top out up the far left arete.
content.protection: Two pads are nice. This climbs over the top of a big boulder.
content.location: Same start as the “warm-up” problem.

content.description: Start just to the left of PPE. Get your right hand in the left hand start hold for PPE, and your left hand on a small incut crimp. Establish on a good foothold, then jump up to the big, incut crimp. From there, take it to the top using the left arêt.I worked this with Andrew Pelton and Nate Iannuccillo and we had varying experiences with the grade. It's likely on the easier side of 7 or even v6 for taller climbers as they can hit the opening move while keeping a foot on. It's probably more v7+ or v8 for shorter climbers as you have to cut feet on the opening move.
content.location: On the DGB.

content.description: Ever felt like your life was just a series of events in which you climb out of a hole you dug for yourself? Me neither, but anyway go all the way down into the hole that is just to the right of No Use for a Name and locate a strangely cramped starting dihedral with a nice left hand underclingerlock™ and a right hand crimp. Strap on a kneebar pad and stem, smear, slap, jam, and grunt your way out the dihedral roof crack using a tricky sequence that keeps you close to the wall and off the ground. A great one to work solo, as you're never more than two feet off the ground and your friends won't have to be there to laugh at you as you try to devise some new kind of martial arts beta to send the climb.
content.protection: pads, a 1" slider pad is useful. kneebar pad useful too
content.location: On the blundercling boulder in a small cave to the right of no use for a name.

content.description: While this looks gabby at first glance, it climbed way better than I was expecting. The only real dab potential I found was swinging feet over for the exit move. Otherwise, it entirely avoids the boulder blocking it. Stylistically, it's a good one to do as preparation for Compression Session (V8 on tier 2). it climbs differently, but shares some elements. Start with a right hand on a sloper pinch and your left on the bottom of the obvious rail on the face. I used low feet. Make some right hand bumps and a heel hook, then get to the lip. Follow the lip left until you can swing your foot to the giant V with a foot in it, and press your way out to the jug. I'm unsure if this is V5 and I just had bad beta, or if it's more in the V6/6+ range. Any thoughts would be greatly appreciate.As this is right on the trail I'm sure it's been done before, so if anyone has info please let me know.
content.protection: A pad for the start, and a few on top of the boulder that's under the line.
content.location: 500 feet up the trail from the kiosk at the start. Just past No Use For A Name and Marmalute.

content.description:
I found some chalk and cleaned boulders in this area, but I don't know how they missed this gem!  It was completely covered in lichen when I found it and quite unclimbable.  After a bunch of cleaning it turned into a great line. 

  Start standing with your hands on either side.  Then desperately muscle your way up the arete. 

  A lower start is probably possible and much harder.
content.location: Walk up the trail until you get to a 12 foot, blank, overhanging boulder on the right.  Turn left off the trail and look for the obvious overhang/nose.

content.description: If you're facing the prow where you stand start for Butterknife, this starts on the right hand side of the boulder roughly where the prow meets the rest of the boulder. There is an obvious seam and flake, which is where the right hand starts (I will upload a photo of the start holds later this week).Start with your right hand on the crimpy edge, and left on a sloper. Then, work your way left along the face using slopers, crimps and a lot of different body positions until you get into the start of the butterknife. From there, top out the butterknife. This is a long, full value climb that favors having dialed beta.
content.protection: 6 pads and spotters. The landing needs a bit of work.
content.location: On the butterknife boulder.

content.description: Start on a left hand crimp and a slopey right hand.  Move into the obvious undercling and work your right hand up the arete.
content.location:
This is one of the first boulders you come to on the boulder loop. Its on the left and can easily be seen from the trail.

7/20/20 Update - Take "your first left" left just after the stairs to a "pair" of boulders with several cleaned faces about 50 +/- feet off the hiking trail. Note that the dead tree pictured in one of the photos is now just a burned stump. RHall NH Admin.

content.description: Start matched with your hands in a horizontal seam.  Get high feet (it's not Lynn Woods so the separate boulder is not "in") and throw to the lip. Mantel and top out.
content.protection: Top out is kind of high so 3-4 pads and a spotter would be nice.
content.location: This route is located on the Butterknife boulder and starts to the left of the prominent roof feature. Walk on the trail past Blundercling. You will get to a part of the trail that has many boulders on it and a big, blank overhang on the right. Turn left off the trail and walk up the hill. Look for the obvious overhang of The Butterknife

content.description: Sit start low on two sidepulls below the start of Bishup Bolder. Pull on and bump your left hand to one of the starting crimps on Bishup. This is the crux, especially for a tall person. Roll out right to another sidepull that's far and low, then get to the big crimp at head hight. From here, I exit left and use the arêt to top out. Going straight up would probably add a grade of difficulty.As I note on Tension, the crux is a small box to fit in. It might be easier for a shorter person, so I would love to get people's thoughts on that. It's really hard to grade a single hard move, so take this grade with a grain of salt. Could be easier, or harder.
content.location: On the Bishup Boulder.

content.description: Stand starting on two crimps. Make a big move up to another crimp.  Finally, wrestle the slopers and the blunt arete to gain the top out.
content.location: Follow the directions as for The Butterknife. This climb is up the hill a little further to the right.

content.description: Start on two crimpy holds and throw up and right to a better edge (or just jump start to that edge) and make a tricky mid-face mantle to stand up and reach the lip. Goes from a sit at V5ish
content.location: Left of N.D.M.P. on the back side of the blundercling boulder. Between the two birches, the left one being a giant rotting stump.

climbs.name: Balls to The Wall (on Balls to walls boulder)

content.description: Starts matched on lower sloper, with your heel on lower left flake. Pull up and shift your weight onto the heel. Go left handed to the crimp left of the sloper (can be grabbed upside-down if you want to pinch). Then throw the right hand out around the arete, there is a slight dish on the arete. Then go left hand around the other side, foot on the start hold and top out.
content.location:
not to far off the path, just take a left before the butterknife boulder and head towards the walls over yonder, it'll be directly next to them.

7/20/20 Update- While true it's not "far from the path" (about 150-200 ft) , that's a bit misleading since it is the furthest away from the hiking trail!  Perhaps a better description would go: Take your "first left" passing by the Blundercling Boulder(s) heading uphill towards a blocky vertical cliff band and three large boulders that are only 10-15 ft from this "wall".  Balls to the Wall is on the last face of the 3rd boulder. (see map.) R Hall, NH Admin.

content.description: This climb starts with one foot on the obvious ledge to the left of "No Use For a Name" and a right on the face. Start with both hands on the arêt, and follow it all the way up until the top lip. Pulling the bulge is the crux. To add some extra spice, you can dyno from the bulge to the lip. You can also up the difficulty by making a few right hand moves on "No Use" while keeping the left on the arêt.
content.location: Right off the trail 500 feet past the start kiosk. Directly on the other side of the boulder that blunder cling is on.

content.description: This has probably been done before, but I thought it was a great problem worth sharing.Start matched on the undercling and pop to a good right hand crimp. Use a small left hand pocket and pop right hand to the arete. Topout has not been cleaned, but it is not very difficult.
content.protection: A few pads for the topout
content.location: On the same boulder as the Lichen Slab, directly  right of it.

content.description: Climb the right of two seams with the help of the Arete. Watch out for the tree behind you if you pitch off.*Named after a Misfits song in honor of the NH State bird
content.location: Wall between Tier 1/2

content.description: Boulders only a short walk up and left of the Boulder Loop hiking trail, but before that trail splits.     Many of the problems and boulders in this area were explored and reported by Jon and "Old Timer" and, before they are moved into this "new" sub-area can be found in the sub-areas "Boulder Loop Trail Bouldering" and "Parking Lot Boulders"
